entries.meaning: (typography) A type of lettering form written lower than the things around it.
examples: In chemical formulas the number of atoms in a molecule is written as a subscript, so we write H2O for water which has two atoms of hydrogen for each one of oxygen.

entries.meaning: (programming) An index into an array or hash.
examples: If the container is subscriptable and you remember the position where a particular piece of data was stored, you can use the subscript to efficiently retrieve the data.

verbs.description: subscript (third-person singular simple present subscripts, present participle subscripting, simple past and past participle subscripted)

entries.meaning: (mathematics, sciences, typography, transitive, of a variable) To provide with a subscript.
examples: As in the chapters on the synchronous model, we use the convention of subscripting a variable by the index of the process at which the variable resides.

entries.meaning: (mathematics, sciences, typography, transitive, of a text) To convert to a subscript form.
(programming, transitive) To access (an array element) by its index.
examples: Avoid subscripting arrays or hashes within loops.
